originalTitle: Russian 'pick-up artist' accused of secretly filming women in Ghana
title: Russian 'pick-up artist' accused of secretly filming women in Ghana
content: Ghana has called on Russia to extradite the man, who is accused of recording sexual encounters without consent.

originalTitle: Planned US-funded baby vaccine trial in Guinea-Bissau blasted by WHO
title: Planned US-funded baby vaccine trial in Guinea-Bissau blasted by WHO
content: Giving some newborns in Guinea-Bissau an established hepatitis B treatment but not others is "unethical", it says.

title: Kenyans drop flowers for Valentine's bouquets of cash. Not everyone is impressed
content: Bouquets of cash have been blooming in popularity in Kenya but recent warnings may slow the trend.

originalTitle: As Sudanese city returns to life after two-year siege, drone threat lingers
title: As Sudanese city returns to life after two-year siege, drone threat lingers
content: Markets reopen in Dilling, South Kordofan’s second largest city. Yet residents face persistent aerial attacks.

originalTitle: Iran seeks to get out of FATF blacklist amid domestic political divisions
title: Iran seeks to get out of FATF blacklist amid domestic political divisions
content: North Korea and Myanmar are other two countries on global financial blacklist as Tehran promises countermeasures.

originalTitle: Iran’s Araghchi slams European powers for ‘irrelevance’ in nuclear talks
title: Iran’s Araghchi slams European powers for ‘irrelevance’ in nuclear talks
content: Foreign minister says regional powers have been 'far more effective' than the European countries.

originalTitle: Iran ready to discuss compromises to reach nuclear deal, minister tells BBC in Tehran
title: Countries Talk for Peace Around the World!
content:
Hello, Young Explorers of Africa!

Hi everyone! It's your kid-friendly news reporter here, bringing you exciting updates from around our big, beautiful world. I hope you are all doing well and learning amazing things at school! Today, we have a very important story from far, far away. It's about how countries talk to each other to make the world a safer and happier place for all of us.

Big News from Far Away Lands!

Imagine two very big friends who need to talk about something very important. That's a little bit like what's happening now. We have news about a country called Iran. It's a country far away from Africa, with its own special people and culture. A person from Iran, named Mr. Majid Takht-Ravanchi, spoke to a news channel called the BBC. The BBC is like a super-duper messenger service that tells people all over the world what is happening. Mr. Takht-Ravanchi said something very interesting. He said Iran is ready to talk and make agreements. These agreements are called "compromises." He wants to reach a special "deal."

What is a "Nuclear Deal"?

Now, this sounds like a big grown-up word, doesn't it? "Nuclear." Let's break it down! Imagine you have a tiny, tiny pebble. So tiny you can barely see it! Inside that pebble, there's amazing energy. Scientists can learn how to take this energy out. When they do it very carefully and smartly, they can make electricity! This electricity can light up our homes, power our schools, and help our hospitals. That's a super good way to use this special energy. This special energy is called "nuclear" energy. **Did you know?** Many countries around the world use nuclear energy to make electricity. It helps keep the lights on and our devices charged! But sometimes, people can also use this special energy to make very, very big bombs. These bombs are not good because they can cause a lot of harm and hurt many people. So, countries try to make sure this special energy is only used for good things, like making electricity, and not for making bombs. A "nuclear deal" is when countries talk and agree on rules. These rules are about how a country uses this special nuclear energy. The deal makes sure that countries use it only for peaceful things, like making electricity, and not for making dangerous bombs. It's like promising to play nicely with a powerful toy.

Talking and Agreeing Together

When grown-ups and countries have problems or important things to discuss, what do they do? They talk! Just like when you talk to your friends or family to solve something. This is what Iran and another big country, America, are trying to do. America is also a very big country, far away from us, across the big ocean. These two countries want to make a special agreement, a "deal." This deal is about making sure nuclear energy is used safely. Making a deal means both sides listen to each other and try to find a way to agree. It's about finding common ground.

Who is Talking for Iran?

The person who spoke to the news was Mr. Majid Takht-Ravanchi. He is like a very important helper or a special messenger for Iran. His job is to talk to people from other countries and share Iran's ideas. He is called a "deputy foreign minister." That's a fancy name, but it just means he helps Iran talk to the rest of the world. He said that Iran is ready to "discuss compromises." What does that mean?

Playing Fair – What is a Compromise?

Imagine you and your friend both want to play with the same ball. You want to play football, but your friend wants to play netball. What do you do? You might say, "Okay, let's play football for a little while, and then we'll play netball." Or maybe you decide to play a new game you both like. That's a compromise! It means both sides give a little bit to get a little bit. It's about meeting in the middle. No one gets everything they want, but everyone gets something good. It helps everyone be happy and keeps friendships strong. **Did you know?** Compromise is a super important skill for life! It helps you get along with your friends, family, and even people from other countries. So, when Mr. Takht-Ravanchi said Iran is ready to discuss compromises, it means they are ready to talk about giving a little bit on some things, if America is also ready to do the same. They want to find a middle way to agree on the nuclear deal.

Whose Turn Is It to Play?

Mr. Takht-Ravanchi used a very cool phrase. He said the "ball was in America's court." Have you ever played a game like football or basketball? When the ball is "in your court" or "at your feet," it means it's your turn to make the next move! It's your turn to dribble, or pass, or shoot! So, what he meant was that Iran has said what they are willing to do. Now, it's America's turn to show that they also want to make a deal. It's America's turn to make a move and show they are ready to talk and compromise too. They want America to "prove that they want to do a deal." It's like passing the ball to the other team and waiting for them to play.

Why is This Important for Us in Africa?

You might be thinking, "This is happening so far away! Why does it matter to me here in Africa?" That's a great question! When big countries like Iran and America talk to each other and try to solve problems peacefully, it makes the whole world a safer place. When there is peace, it means less fighting and more opportunities for everyone. Think about it: if countries are fighting, they can't send help to places that need it, or share new ideas for medicine, or trade things that make our lives better. But when countries talk and agree, they can work together! This means we can all learn from each other. Countries can share knowledge to grow more food, find cures for sickness, and build better schools. It helps create a world where children everywhere, including you, can grow up safe, happy, and healthy. Peace in one part of the world can help bring peace everywhere! **Did you know?** When countries talk and solve problems without fighting, it's called diplomacy. Diplomats are like superheroes who use words instead of weapons to keep the peace!

Let's Hope for Good News!

So, that's the big news from far away! Iran is ready to talk and compromise, and they are waiting for America to make the next move. We hope that these big countries keep talking and find a way to make a deal. When they do, it will be a good thing for peace and safety for everyone, all around the world, including right here in our wonderful continent of Africa. Let's all hope for good news and for countries to work together for a brighter future! Stay curious, young reporters!
summary: Iran says it is ready to talk and make agreements with America about how to use special energy, hoping to make the world a safer place for everyone.
whyMatters: This is important because when big countries talk and agree, instead of fighting, it helps keep the whole world peaceful and safe. A peaceful world means children everywhere, including in Africa, can grow up happily, with more chances to learn and play without worry.

originalTitle: Eleven killed in Israeli strikes on Gaza, rescuers say
title: Eleven killed in Israeli strikes on Gaza, rescuers say
content: The Palestinian Red Crescent say a strike on a tent encampment in northern Gaza killed at least six people.

title: Russia killed opposition leader Alexei Navalny using dart frog toxin, UK says
content: There is no innocent explanation for the toxin being found in samples taken from Navalny's body, Foreign Office says.

title: 'The officials looked petrified' - was Villa Park chaos advert for VAR?
content: Newcastle United beat Aston Villa in the FA Cup fourth round in a match dominated by a number of controversial decisions without VAR.

originalTitle: Salah shines as Liverpool comfortably beat Brighton
title: Salah shines as Liverpool comfortably beat Brighton
content: Goals from Curtis Jones, Dominik Szoboszlai and Mohamed Salah give Liverpool a comfortable 3-0 win over Brighton in the fourth round of the FA Cup at Anfield.
